l. 379. crederes, ‘anyone who had seen the Africans might have taken them for a Roman line, so armed were they with Roman armour, taken some at the Trebia, but the greater part at lake Thrasymene.’ Polybius' account is almost word for word the same here. He adds, however, that Hannibal led forward the Spaniards and the Gauls in front of the rest, so as to make his centre in the form of a crescent, μηνοειδὲς ποιῶν τὸ κύρτωμα. Thus the native Africans would give con- fidence to the weaker Europeans, and also prevent their desertion. Resides, Hannibal could least spare Africans, and the first shower of darts might as well fall on the least valuable of his forces.
